Issues.Title: Allow specifying custom NGCC lockfile location (cannot build in parallel with Ivy)
Issues.Body:
<!--🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅

Oh hi there! 😄 

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅🔅-->


# 🚀 feature request

### Relevant Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages the are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ✍️edit: --> This feature request is for @angular/compiler-cli


### Description
I am running multiple webpack build pipelines simultaneously  in CI. It does work without Ivy, but with Ivy (Angular 9 rc 11) it fails with:
```
(If you are sure no ngcc process is running then you should delete the lockfile at /drone/src/github.com/Rush/angular-app/node_modules/@angular/compiler-cli/ngcc/__ngcc_lock_file__.)
```

### Describe the solution you'd like
This line should allow overwriting the lock file location:
https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/d15cf60c4969c4da081d0efdbc818abfd3fe43eb/packages/compiler-cli/ngcc/src/execution/lock_file.ts#L20
Perhaps like so:
```
 lockFilePath = process.env.ANGULAR_NGCC_LOCK_FILE_PATH || 
      this.fs.resolve(require.resolve('@angular/compiler-cli/ngcc'), '../__ngcc_lock_file__');
```

I think this is safe cause all simultaneous compiles are happening in Webpack so they're not conflicting with each other. @petebacondarwin @AndrewKushnir 

Not having this would cause my builds running 10x more slowly due to a lot of parallelism.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
Disabling the lock file with a config option.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Allow specifying custom NGCC lockfile location (cannot build in parallel with Ivy)" (#35000)

Issues.Title: Animations metadata is not inherited to sub-classed components
Issues.Body:
In Ivy, the `@Component({...})` metadata is inherited from a parent class. However, it appears that `animations` is not included.

This causes an issue when a parent class component defines animations host bindings and an animations definition, but the subclassed component only receives the host bindings.

The renderer throws an error but it is not helpful:
`Found the synthetic property @state. Please include either "BrowserAnimationsModule" or "NoopAnimationsModule" in your application.`

Reproduction: https://stackblitz.com/edit/ivy-ejv3ha?file=src/app/hello.component.ts
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Animations metadata is not inherited to sub-classed components" (#34999)

Issues.Title: refactor(language-service): make findOutputBinding a utility function
Issues.Body:
This commit makes `findOutputBinding` a utility function for the
language service, which will be used by the `expression_diagnostics`
module in #34570. Keeping the function in `locate_symbol` results in a
circular dependency between `expression_diagnostics` and
`locate_symbol`.

Issues.Title: ci: don't run benchmark_tests on CI
Issues.Body:
Since we don't do anything with the results of the benchmark_test
executions on CI, we should not run them.  Additionally, since
benchmarks are meant to test in a consistent environment, we should
execute the benchmark tests locally rather than on RBE executors.

Issues.Title: fix(language-service): prune duplicate returned definitions
Issues.Body:
Sometimes, a request for definitions will return multiple of the same
definition. This can happen in at least the cases of

- two-way bindings (one of the same definition for the property and
  event binding)
- multiple template binding expressions in the same attribute
  - something like "*ngFor="let i of items; trackBy: test" has two
    template bindings, resulting in two template binding ASTs at the
    same location (the attribute span). The language service then parses
    both of these bindings individually, resulting in two independent
    but identical definitions. For more context, see https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/34847#discussion_r371006680.

This commit prunes duplicate definitions by signing definitions with
their location, and checking if that location signature has been seen in
a previous definition returned to the client.

Issues.Title: Setting ViewChild property in parent accessor causes error
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/core ### Is this a regression? Yes, t[his works](https://stackblitz.com/edit/component-accessor-v8?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.html) in Angular 8.x ### Description When an `@Input` property has a setter and tries to update a property of a `@ViewChild`, the app errors ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction `CustomDirective` is a simple directive w/ a single property: `public id: string`; `CustomComponent` is a simple component. `CustomComponent` has an instance of `CustomDirective` in its view and a reference to that instance. `CustomComponent` has a single `@Input` property w/ `get` and `set` accessors. The `set` accessor manipulates the `id` property of `this.directive`: ``` @ViewChild(CustomDirective) private directive: CustomDirective @Input() public get id(): string { return this._id; } public set id(val: string) { this._id = val; this.directive.id = val; } ``` [Github](https://github.com/ViktorSlavov/angular-viewchild-error) When you run the app, there is an error in the console. ## 🔥 Exception or Error

Issues.Body:
# 🚀 Feature request

### Command (mark with an `x`)
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [x] serve
- [x] test
- [x] e2e

- [ ] add

### Description
![Screenshot 2020-01-27 at 13 39 39](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13135149/73175570-ce02f480-410a-11ea-97d2-c03d03001462.png)

In the above Angular CLI build error, the file name is too bright to be easily read. I haven't verified this scientifically using contrast checkers, but I'm pretty sure it wouldn't pass.

### Describe the solution you'd like
Could you use a darker color ?

### Describe alternatives you've considered
Manually filtering colors through the terminal, but this is cumbersome. Colors are too useful to be disabled.

PS: I know `_string` isn't a valid Typescript type 😉 Just had to find a way to create an error.

Issues.Title: "angularCompilerOptions" migration error running `ng update` from v8 -> v9
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [x] update ### Is this a regression? unknown ### Description When using `ng update @angular/core --force --migrate-only --from=8`, I received the following error: ```bash TypeScript project "lib/tsconfig.lib.json" has configuration errors. This could cause an incomplete migration. Please fix the following failures and rerun the migration: error TS100: Angular compiler option "flatModuleIndex" requires one and only one .ts file in the "files" field. ``` I tracked the error down to the inclusion of ```json "angularCompilerOptions": { "flatModuleId": "AUTOGENERATED", "flatModuleOutFile": "AUTOGENERATED" } ``` In one of my library's `tsconfig.lib.json` files. I tried deleting both ```json "flatModuleId": "AUTOGENERATED", "flatModuleOutFile": "AUTOGENERATED" ``` And the migration completes successfully. I believe both `"flatModuleId"` and `"flatModuleOutFile"` were added by a previous version of the angular CLI (version 7?) when I generated this library (via `ng g library`). If these compiler options are no longer needed by the current CLI, I would expect the migration to remove them without error. The error was made more confusing because the error message references an angular configuration option that is not actually present in my tsConfig file: `"flatModuleIndex"`. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction A reproduction repo can be found here: https://gitlab.com/service-work/is-loading/tree/angular-update-issue From the repo root, run 1. `yarn install` 2. `yarn ng update @angular/core --force --migrate-only --from=8` ## 🔥 Exception or Error 
TypeScript project "lib/tsconfig.lib.json" has configuration errors. This could cause an incomplete migration. Please fix the following failures and rerun the migration:
    error TS100: Angular compiler option "flatModuleIndex" requires one and only one .ts file in the "files" field.

Issues.Title: fix(@schematics/angular): add compliance with no-any lint rule
Issues.Body:
Fixes #16770

Make Angular CLI schematics compliant with `no-any` TSLint rule.

For `test.ts` files, as they are just configuration files for unit tests, not real code, the rule is just disabled.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@schematics/angular): add compliance with no-any lint rule" (#16771)

Issues.Title: Schematics compliance with no-any lint rule
Issues.Body:
# 🚀 Feature request

### Command
- [x] lint

### Description

It's a very good practice in TypeScript to enable the `no-any` TSLint rule, which ensures that no `any` is used, as it's not type safe. Since [TypeScript 3.0](http://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/release-notes/typescript-3-0.html#new-unknown-top-type), when a value type is really not known, the right type is `unknown`, which is type safe.

### Describe the solution you'd like

It would be nice if Angular CLI schematics could be compliant with that lint rule by default. It's currently not the case:
- in `test.ts` configuration files (application and library)
- in pipe schematic
- in e2e boilerplate

That would also be more consistent with other schematics where unknown values are indeed typed as `unknown` (like in the [interceptor schematic](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/schematics/angular/interceptor/files/__name%40dasherize%40if-flat__/__name%40dasherize__.interceptor.ts.template)).

PR done in #16771. Note that it does not enable the lint rule, it just makes schematics compliant with it, so it has no consequences at all.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Schematics compliance with no-any lint rule" (#16770)

Issues.Title: fix(@schematics/angular): add compliance with call-signature lint rule
Issues.Body:
Fixes #16754 

Make Angular CLI schematics compliant with `typedef: ["call-signature"]` TSLint rule.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@schematics/angular): add compliance with call-signature lint rule" (#16755)

Issues.Title: Schematics compliance with call-signature lint rule
Issues.Body:
# 🚀 Feature request

### Command
- [x] lint

### Description

It's a very good practice in TypeScript to enable the `typedef: ["call-signature"]` TSLint rule, which ensures that functions return type is explicit.

Why?
- because otherwise TypeScript infers the return type, but based on the code, which assumes the code is correct (while it may not);
- it's the minimal documentation that should be expected in any code.

### Describe the solution you'd like

It would be nice if Angular CLI schematics could be compliant with that lint rule by default. It's currently not the case:
- in component schematic `ngOnInit()`
- in e2e schematics

The first one is especially annoying as then we need to add `: void` each time we create a new component.

That would also be more consistent with other schematics where the functions return type is indeed explicit (like guards, interceptors, etc.).

PR done in #16755. Note that it does not enable the lint rule, it just makes schematics compliant with it, so it has no consequences at all.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Schematics compliance with call-signature lint rule" (#16754)

Issues.Title: Angular CLI component generations template for .spec.ts is missing an await
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are effected by this bug? -->
<!-- ✍️edit: -->

- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [x] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc


### Is this a regression?
No


### Description
Angular CLI component generations template for `.spec.ts` is missing an `await`.
The code generated looks like this:

```JavaScript
  beforeEach(async(() => {
    TestBed.configureTestingModule({
      declarations: [ MyComponent ]
    })
    .compileComponents();
  }));
```

The anonymous function was made `async` in this issue: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/4774

But just making the function `async` will not make it wait for the asynchronous call to `compileComponents()`.

The code should be changed to this (added `await`):
```JavaScript
  beforeEach(async(() => {
    await TestBed.configureTestingModule({
      declarations: [ MyComponent ]
    })
    .compileComponents();
  }));
```

Source code: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/master/packages/schematics/angular/component/files/__name%40dasherize%40if-flat__/__name%40dasherize__.__type%40dasherize__.spec.ts.template


## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction
Simply generate a new component with tests:
```
ng generate component my-component
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Angular CLI component generations template for .spec.ts is missing an await" (#16767)

Issues.Title: ng add --registry not working
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [x] add - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Unsure, probably not. ### Description When trying to install a package with `ng add` from a local npm registry, using `ng add package-name --registry=http://localhost:4873/` (Verdaccio in my case), `ng add` seems to ignore the `--registry` parameter and continues to try and pull the package from the registry url set in npm config. If I set the npm registry to localhost manually, ng add works fine. `npm config set registry http://localhost:4873` Previous issue which asked for this feature: #14189. PR which supposedly added this feature: #14285. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction Prerequisites: - Have Verdaccio or any other private / local npm registry running. - Have some package published in the private registry. Steps: 1. Generate new Angular project with `ng new`. 2. Run `ng add package-name --registry=http://localhost:4873`, replace package name and url with your own. 3. It will now throw an error because it can't find the package on `https://registry.npmjs.org/`, obviously. ## 🔥 Exception or Error 
An unhandled exception occurred: npm ERR! code E404
npm ERR! 404 Not Found - GET https://registry.npmjs.org/package-name - Not found
npm ERR! 404
npm ERR! 404  'package-name@latest' is not in the npm registry.
npm ERR! 404 You should bug the author to publish it (or use the name yourself!)
npm ERR! 404
npm ERR! 404 Note that you can also install from a
npm ERR! 404 tarball, folder, http url, or git url.
## 🌍 Your Environment 
Angular CLI: 8.3.23
Node: 13.0.1
OS: win32 x64
Angular: 8.2.14

... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router

Issues.Title: extract-css option seems to be broken
Issues.Body:
Extract-css option seems to be broken. ### Is this a regression? Not sure ### Description I've created new minimal project with angular 8.2.14. Created 2 new components with ViewEncapsulation.None. Ran `ng build --prod --extract-css` and expected to be able to find styles from components in the generated .css. All components styles remains in .js Build generates 2 .css files. Both has exactly the same content from the main styless.less file. Used LESS for styles, but seems that SASS behaves exactly the same. ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction Here's a demo repo with Angular 8.2.14 https://github.com/jodaka/angular-extract-css-problem/tree/ng8 master branch is similar but runs Angular 9.rc11 run `ng build --prod` and inspect generated css in `dist/test` ## 🌍 Your Environment **Angular Version:** 
Angular CLI: 8.3.20
Node: 13.6.0
OS: darwin x64
Angular: 8.2.14

Issues.Title: child component not get display while using router-outlet active event to get child component instance
Issues.Body:
While using router-outlet, i have used “**active**” event ton take child component instance. > A router outlet will emit an activate event any time a new component > is being instantiated, and a deactivate event when it is being > destroyed. **Sample** - https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-router-basic-example-a9jpsd?file=app/app.component.ts Example code – > App.component.html
> App.component.ts public onRouterOutletActivate(event : any) { console.log(event); } But child component not get displayed at initial loading, but element is in DOM.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "child component not get display while using router-outlet active event to get child component instance" (#16762)

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): add webpack transformer to extract-i18n builder
Issues.Body:
The purpose of this PR is to add a Webpack configuration transformer in order to support i18n for custom webpack builds (3rd party builders).  
More info [here](https://github.com/just-jeb/angular-builders/issues/659).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): add webpack transformer to extract-i18n builder" (#16759)

Issues.Title: Add support for *.html via the raw-loader to the webpack.config generated by @angular-devkit/build-angular:karma
Issues.Body:
# 🚀 Feature Request: Add support for *.html via the raw-loader to the webpack.config generated by @angular-devkit/build-angular:karma

### Command (mark with an `x`)
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [x] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description

#### Background
I am working on a legacy AngularJS application. Migrating the entire code base to Angular is not technically viable at this point in time. As a solution I have dual bootstrap the AngularJS application with the Angular ngUpgrade module so the application can be migrated over time. 

At this initial stage of the project I am using the existing webpack.config to build the app. My webpack.config handles the transpilation of the Typescript and Angular by way of the ts-loader. Everything compiles and loads and I can proceed with Angular while maintaining existing AngularJS code.

At present I do not get the full benefit of the Angular CLI, but will in future as more legacy code is migrated and the CLI is used to it's full capability. At present thou it should be possible for me to use the lint and test commands against all new Angular code even thou it isn't being built or served by the Angular CLI.

#### The actual feature request

The issue comes into play when I attempt to use `ng test` to test new Angular components. `ng test`, or more specifically the angular-devkit/build-angular:karma plugin. Out of the box it doesn't support native ES6 imports for html files within Angular components. Running `ng test` on files written like:

```
import {Component} from '@angular/core';

import template from './my-component.component.html';

@Component({
    selector: 'my-component',
    template
})
public class MyComponent {
```

results in:

```
ERROR in ./src/app/my-component/my-component.component.html 1:0
Module parse failed: Unexpected token (1:0)
You may need an appropriate loader to handle this file type, currently no loaders are configured to process this file. See https://webpack.js.org/concepts#loaders
```

I cannot use the Angular CLI to build at this time, so using templateUrl is out as it results distribution  making requests to the server for the templates. I assume this is because I don't have a full AOT configuration provided natively by the Angular CLI.

### Describe the solution you'd like

I would like the `\.html$` files to be handled by the webpack config generated by @angular-devkit/build-angular/plugins/karma`. This can be achieved simply by adding (or something similar):

```
webpackConfig.module.rules.push({
    test: /\.html$/,
    use: [{loader: 'raw-loader'}]
});
```

I was thinking `raw-loader` only because you already have it as a dependency; otherwise `html-loader` would also work with the additional configuration option for `caseSensitive: true`. It's a little insane that the plugin supports imports of every other typical file type but not html:

```
[
  {
    test: /\.(eot|svg|cur|jpg|png|webp|gif|otf|ttf|woff|woff2|ani)$/,
    loader: 'file-loader',
    options: { name: '[name].[ext]' }
  },
  {
    test: /[\/\\]@angular[\/\\]core[\/\\].+\.js$/,
    parser: { system: true }
  },
  { test: /[\/\\]hot[\/\\]emitter\.js$/, parser: { node: [Object] } },
  {
    test: /[\/\\]webpack-dev-server[\/\\]client[\/\\]utils[\/\\]createSocketUrl\.js$/,
    parser: { node: [Object] }
  },
  { test: /\.js$/, exclude: /(ngfactory|ngstyle)\.js$/ },
  {
    test: /\.js$/,
    exclude: /(ngfactory|ngstyle)\.js$/,
    enforce: 'pre'
  },
  { exclude: [], test: /\.css$/, use: [ [Object], [Object] ] },
  {
    exclude: [],
    test: /\.scss$|\.sass$/,
    use: [ [Object], [Object], [Object] ]
  },
  {
    exclude: [],
    test: /\.less$/,
    use: [ [Object], [Object], [Object] ]
  },
  {
    exclude: [],
    test: /\.styl$/,
    use: [ [Object], [Object], [Object] ]
  },
  {
    test: /\.tsx?$/,
    loader: '/<omitted>/node_modules/@angular-devkit/build-angular/node_modules/@ngtools/webpack/src/index.js'
  },
  {
    test: /\.(jsx?|tsx?)$/,
    loader: '/<omitted>/node_modules/coverage-istanbul-loader/lib/index.js',
    options: { esModules: true },
    enforce: 'post',
    exclude: [ /\.(e2e|spec)\.ts$/, /node_modules/ ],
    include: '<omitted>'
  }
]
```

This shouldn't impact the usage of Angular's template or templateUrls because they aren't native requires or imports; just strings and webpack will ignore them.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

I have tried several work arounds including attempting to preprocess the files like in AngularJS and replace templateUrl with the embedded html string. Looked into other angular tooling that will build angular in my existing webpack config; but all these solutions feel dirty.

My least offensive workaround for my issue is to publish my own hacked version of the angular-devkit/build-angular library that applies the above mentioned patch so I can process test files in a way I expect until which time I can move to a world strictly with the angular-cli.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Add support for *.html via the raw-loader to the webpack.config generated by @angular-devkit/build-angular:karma" (#16746)

Issues.Title: Debugging EventEmitter subscription crashes Chrome
Issues.Body:
# 🐞 Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [X ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? I do not know. I have not debugged EventEmitter subscriber functions in other versions of Angular. ### Description An inherited implementation component (mypage.component.ts implements base) with a child component (searchbar.component.ts) crashes Chrome if a debug breakpoint is set inside the parent's subscriber function (where the emitted value is received). ## 🔬 Minimal Reproduction I have a base component (base.component.ts), an inherited implementation component (mypage.component.ts implements base). The implementation contains a child component (searchbar.component.ts). The child component contains a SELECT element. The SELECT element emits a value on its (change) function. The emitted value is caught by the parent component's subscriber function and printed to the console. No problem. However, using Visual Studio Code v1.41.1 (2019Dec18) to debug the subscriber function while running Chrome 76.0.3809.146 as the runtime environment, a breakpoint set anywhere inside the parent's subscriber function will stop the code and allow inspection of values. However, when F5 (continue) is activated, Chrome immediately crashes. ## 🔥 Exception or Error 



If "Aww, Snap" is an error code from Chrome then this is what I get :)
## 🌍 Your Environment

rxjs                              6.5.3

node (npm) version     6.9.0
**Anything else relevant?** Could not get an Edge debug runtime up and going in short order for testing Windows 10

Issues.Title: drag and drop with more than 2 vertical stacked lists don't always work
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction


https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-gytt6j


Steps to reproduce:
1. Drag an item from Todo down to done2.   
2. Drop the item right in the box of done2
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

Item drops to done2.


#### Actual Behavior

Item drops in the middle (wrong) list.

What seems to happen is that when you move an item out of the todo list, the various elements on the screen move up when the item leaves the drop zone of todo.  However, it appears that the drop zones for done and done2 are still in their original positions.  So, if you try to drop where done2 is now visually, it doesn't drop where its supposed to.  If you drop the item where done2 WAS before everything moved up, it will work.  

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2.14
- CDK/Material: 8.2.3
- Browser(s): Chrome 79
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu):  Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "drag and drop with more than 2 vertical stacked lists don't always work" (#18305)

Issues.Title: Deleting an mdc chip does not work when animations are disabled
Issues.Body:
MDC chip foundation relies on the transition animation for the exit class for processing chip deletion:
https://github.com/material-components/material-components-web/blob/302cfd02ace89acf74c90dd13e0a99afc6112fbc/packages/mdc-chips/chip/foundation.ts#L156

When using `NoopAnimationModule` transitions are disabled via the `_mat-animation-noopable` class:
https://github.com/angular/components/blob/0760454aefd5315ba56d6793c6fcee34c9165e04/src/material-experimental/mdc-chips/chip.ts#L108
https://github.com/angular/components/blob/0760454aefd5315ba56d6793c6fcee34c9165e04/src/material/core/style/_noop-animation.scss#L18

This means that any application using the `NoopAnimationModule` (mostly tests) will not handle chip deletion correctly. This could be solved by having a special class that makes transition durations very short when a transition is required for the component to work correctly.

A harder to solve problem (and one that would need to be solved in MDC foundation itself) may be applications that disable transitions with a global css override like `* { transition: none; }`

One additional note: this issue was observed when using the mdc chips with Angular Ivy enabled. For some reason, the `_mat-animation-noopable` class isn't being added to the chip when View Engine is enabled (and I have not investigated why that is).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Deleting an mdc chip does not work when animations are disabled" (#18303)

2. and then in DatepickerEn class I am simply setting:

export class DatepickerEn  extends MatDatepickerIntl  {

}
openCalendarLabel = 'Open Datepicker'
 }

But again, it just works fine for 1 language. How can I include 2 language?

Issues.Title: feat: Focus indicators
Issues.Body:
This PR adds two CSS mixins that add strong focus styles (i.e. focus indicators) to all Material and MDC components.
- `mat-strong-focus-indicators`: Mixin that adds strong focus styles to all Material components.
- `mat-mdc-strong-focus-indicators`: Mixin that adds strong focus styles to all (currently implemented) MDC components.

Notes:
- Should we squash/amend these commits before merging to follow the commit message guidelines? If so, I'm not sure I can do this as an outside contributor.
- A few of these commits are authored by 4220717+zelliott@users.noreply.github.com instead of zell@google.com... causing CLA to fail. Again, I don't think I can edit the commit author emails as a contributor.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat: Focus indicators" (#18299)

Issues.Title: mat-slider: disable special styling on minimum value
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

If a `<mat-slider>` is set to its minimum value, it adds a special class (`.mat-slider-min-value`) that changes the styling of the slider thumb. It would be useful to disable this behavior or adjust the value where this "resting state" occurs.

#### Use Case

In our scenario, the slider ranges from negative to positive values, so the minimum value is not semantically different to other values (except maybe the zero position). It would be nice to visually represent this equality.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "mat-slider: disable special styling on minimum value" (#18298)

Issues.Title: fix(drag-drop): auto scrolling not working if list uses scroll snapping
Issues.Body:
When scrolling a drop list we increment `scrollTop` or `scrollLeft`, but if the list has scroll snapping the browser will only scroll it according to the snap points. These changes reset the scroll snapping while the user is dragging.

Fixes #18162.

Issues.Title: refactor(datepicker): set up date range picker classes
Issues.Body:
Moves some things around to set up the date range picker. Includes:
* Moves all of the datepicker logic into a base class so that it can be reused between the single and range selection.
* Makes the input being passed into a datepicker generic so that we can strongly type `MatDatepicker` to `MatDatepickerInput` and `MatDateRangePicker` to `MatDateRangeInput`.
* Sets up min, max and date filter validation for the date range picker.
* Hooks up the date range picker to the date range input.
* Makes it so that a generic datepicker can be passed to a datepicker toggle.
* Adds a `DateFilterFn` type so we don't have to repeat the signature for the filter function everywhere.

Note that while picking a date range somewhat works now, it's still a bit broken. The primary goal of these changes was to have all of components in place and wired up so that we can start working on the UI in follow-up PRs.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(datepicker): set up date range picker classes" (#18292)

Issues.Title: fix(slide-toggle): clicks not landing correctly in some cases on Chrome
Issues.Body:
Any time the slide toggle host receives focus we forward it immediately to the underlying `input` element. This bouncing around of focus seems to interrupt click events in some cases on Chrome. These changes make it so that we only forward focus for events originating from the keyboard or programmatically.

Fixes #18269.

Issues.Title: feat(cdk/focus-trap) Add ConfigurableFocusTrap tab-wrapping strategies
Issues.Body:
This commit adds a new required strategy parameter to ConfigurableFocusTrap that dictates how it wraps tab, and two implementations of the new strategy.

TabStopFocusTrapWrapStrategy has the same behavior as legacy FocusTrap. It adds hidden tab stops that redirect focus before and after the FocusTrap elements.

TabListenerFocusTrapWrapStrategy caches the first and last element in
the ConfigurableFocusTrap. It intercepts tab/shift-tab on these elements
in order to wrap tab. It updates the cache when the FocusTrap DOM subtree
has a tab-relevant change.

For now, TabStopFocusTrapWrapStrategy is the default strategy in ConfigurableFocusTrapFactory, to simplify migration.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(cdk/focus-trap) Add ConfigurableFocusTrap tab-wrapping strategies" (#18282)

Issues.Title: Add Navigation Rail Sidenav Component
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

This was [just added](https://material.io/components/navigation-rail/) to the official Material Design spec. Navigation rails provide ergonomic movement between primary destinations in apps. YouTube and Google Photos are a couple of examples that use this component.

#### Use Case

The rail is a side navigation component that displays three to seven app destinations and, optionally, a Floating Action Button. Each destination is represented by an icon and a text label.

The rail can function on its own at larger screen sizes, such as desktop and tablet. When users transition between screen sizes and devices, the rail can also complement other navigation components, such as bottom navigation.

#### Preview
![](https://storage.googleapis.com/spec-host/mio-staging%2Fmio-components%2F1579302979877%2Fassets%2F16RFbe_aL_2_gNzrpCWu-wXNAJjouLRlm%2Frail-anatomy-container-dense.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add Navigation Rail Sidenav Component" (#18280)
